city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Soooo good!  I used a combo of shredded cheddar, bread crumbs, and corn flakes (actually threw in the crumbs from a Cheese-Nip box as well) to create the breading.  Also added extra cheese on top.  So delicious!  It's a constant request in the house.  Edit:  I've made this so many times and had so much fun playing around with it that I want to share - 1 cup of crackers (Ritz, cornflakes, saltines, cheese-nips, anything!), 1/2c parm chz, 1 1/2c cheddar, 1/2c bread crumbs.  I also dip the chicken in flour before the butter to help it stick.  This is a great recipe to be adventurous with - do not hesitate to play around!!!  Update 2:  I've discovered Panko bread crumbs to replace the standard crumbs.  WOW!  MUCH crispier and gives it that texture that I've noticed a lot of reviews say is missing.  No panko... try coursely crushing some croutons.

GREAT!!  only thing i did differently was to put a thin layer of the bread crumb mixture on the bottom of the baking dish before i put the chicken in. (just to keep the bottom of the chicken from getting soggy)  worked great!

None
text:
This is delicious!  I made a few changes.  I used half butter, half olive oil.  Also used Italian herbed bread crumbs and a variety of Italian seasonings.  I didn't have chicken breasts, so I used chicken tenders (still flattened them though).  I greased the pan and followed others' suggestions by putting down a thin layer of bread crumbs in the pan before laying down the chicken.  The chicken tenders only took 18 minutes to bake, and then, following others' suggestions, I broiled the chicken for another 2 minutes.  I HIGHLY recommend broiling the chicken at the end because it gives it a delicious crunch!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
An acceptable, but rather ordinary chicken recipe--kind of "ho hum." I'm sure I would have been a bigger fan of this when I was still cooking for my kids when they were younger, but as grown-ups we've moved kind of beyond your average Shake and Bake type chicken. I used crushed cornflakes rather than crumbs, and dill for the oregano, but nothing made this chicken "wake up."  On the upside, this is a "safe" chicken recipe, as even the pickiest of eaters wouldn't be able to find something not to like here--no unusual spices or blending of flavors. It was a little too buttery, however, so for those who would like to give this recipe a try I might suggest coating the chicken in egg rather than melted butter, and maybe drizzling a little butter over the top before baking.

text:
Note:

Use an aluminum/foil pan for this recipe- it keeps the chicken from getting soggy. Also, throw the ingredients into a processor- it blends everything up all nice and makes it easier to coat the chicken.

text:
This dish has a fabulous flavor. The chicken was swimming in butter so the next time I prepare I will place it on a roaster rack. I did not pound thin and I baked it for 1 hour 15 minutes and it came out perfect. I didn't use fresh garlic but rather from the jar and I used 4 teaspoons as we are garlic lovers and that was just right for us. I used garlic and herb seasoned bread crumbs. I thought that I could have omitted the salt. I will definitely make this again but I hated that the bread crumbs became soggy in the butter. Thanks for sharing!

text:
This is a great, tasty and easy chicken dish.  I used sharp cheddar cheese in this.  I omitted the extra salt and used unsalted butter; as the cheeses are salty enough.  I scaled the recipe down to 2 servings and the proportions were just perfect.  I had to bake mine for extra time because my breasts were still partially frozen.  I didn't pound them either, and the chicken was so tender you could cut it with a fork.  Served with mashed potatoes and steamed baby carrots.

None
text:
This recipe is even better when you coat the breasts with flour first, then the garlic butter, then the breadcrumb mixture less the cheddar cheese.  Brown for about 2 minutes per side in a cast iron skillet, transfer to serving plates, top with cheese and put it in the microwave for 2 1/2 minutes.  Mine end up perfectly moist and cooked and not dry which will happen if oven-baked.  My process works for any kind of coating you want to put on CBs and they're done in about five minutes.

text:
This was a great recipe!  I love baked chicken because it's so easy and this one combined my favorites, garlic and cheese!  I loved that I had everything I needed on hand, so it wasn't complicated.  One thing was that I wasn't sure how thin to pound the chicken, so I didn't go too crazy, I just kind of evened out the thicker spot.  The thing that I think just made it was using homeade breadcrumbs.  I just freeze the heals of our whole wheat bread and then grind them up in the blender and store the crumbs in the freezer so they're ready to go.  These bread crumbs gave the chicken such great texture, we loved it!  We will definitly make this again.

I made this chicken last night and it was a BIG hit!  My husband called it the best chicken dish ever! The only modifications I made were to halve the recipe, and I used fresh tarragon, fresh chives, salt, pepper and dried basil for the spices. For optimum flavor, use robust cheeses -- I used Baldersons 3 yr old Cheddar, and a good quality Parmesan (Reggianno).  Awesome results and will make this again often. Served it with Singapore noodles and green beans. Enjoy!

None
text:
I've made this several times for my family, they love it. I did change the recipe a little. I use a combo of Panko bread crumbs and dry Italian bread crumbs and also add granulated garlic and some fresh grated Parmigiano-reggiano to the crumb mixture. Once the chicken has been dipped in the garlic butter and crumbs, I let it rest in the fridge for at least an hour before baking and add a bit more shredded Cheddar to the top of each breast. The crust is awesomely crispier if you let it rest first.

fergabees

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an "okay" idea, but it needs alot of help.  Add more spices because its bland.  Only coat the top of the chicken with the breaded mixture because the bottom does not get crispy and is very soggy!  I took the advice of the others on here who have said the bottom turns out too soggy.  The tip was to put bread crumbs in the bottom of your pan before you lay your chicken on top.  It didnt help much and just burned to the bottom of the pan when you put it on broil for the last few minutes.  Next time I will leave the back side uncoated to avoid the mushy mess.  Its a MUST to put this on broil otherwise it will not be brown or crisp..just a pale mush with cheese on top.!  The picture shown for this recipe can NOT be from following these instructions.  In the picture the chicken looks brown and the coating looks appitizing.  If that chicken is brown then that cheese on top would not look like it was just sprinkled on with a few minutes of melt time.  I followed these instructions and my chicken did not look like that.   Beware when you cook this and use your own judgement b/c these instructions will not get you the results you see in the picture.

text:
I made this using chicken tenders.  I didn't have parsley and used a little basil & oregano as well as seasoned garlic salt & pepper.  I have read some low reviews indicating there wasn't enough flavor.  That's simply because there wasn't enough seasoning added.  I didn't follow the recipe there but added the amount of seasoning I typically use when fixing chicken.  The taste was wonderful - my daughter announced that it was her new favorite dish.  The best part of the chicken dish were the little bits of cheese and bread crumbs at the bottom of the pan - in the wonderful garlic-flavored butter.  Definitely a keeper make-again recipe!

Looked great when it came out of the oven and TASTED even better! :) I did not have the utensils to pound the breasts thin & reduced to 2 servings. Other than using a shredded mozzerella & provelone blend in place of parmesan I follwed the proportionate recipe exactly. I will DEFINATELY make this again!!!

Ok this recipe is awesome. If you like garlic, this is it! I thought this was the strangest combination, cheddar and garlic, but I was SO SO SO happy with the results. I've been searching for the perfect chicken recipe that you can use with anything and this is it for me! text:
We love this dish!  I've cooked it three times now.  I typically scale the dish to 4 servings for 3 large breasts and it works out great.  Echo everyone else:  1)  coat the baking dish with breadcrumbs to avoid sticking and to sop up any unwanted runoff  2)  BROIL for the last 2-3 minutes for a great crunchy texture.  I make this as-stated but I use about 1 teaspoon of Italian seasoning in place of the parsley and organo.  I also use seasoned breadcrumbs.   I served it with sautéed asparagus and garlic mashed potatoes and it's a win.  Thanks for sharing this yummy recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! Yes, fattening, but a treat to repeat!  As for those trying to cut the butter with EVOO, not only will it need to be cooked at a higher temp to get the crispness, but it will also slightly change the taste of the cheese.  Suck it up & just use butter...just don't make it every day!  I made 2 simple changes...to make a more intense cheese flavor, I added some ground mustard and I did omit the salt, but added a dash of garlic salt.  As for the prep...I noticed some said they had a problem getting the cheese to stick to the chicken in the bread mixture.  I threw my bag of cheese in the freezer for about 20 min, then chopped it up a bit when it was super cold.  When mixed with the crumbs, it stuck just fine.  This is a keeper.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
Not sure whether I should be reviewing this because instead of chicken I used... TOFU!  I was looking for something a little different, and this was just delicious.  My success with this makes me think that this would be a great recipe not just for chicken but other white meats and vegetables (eggplant would be beautiful!).  Easy, and very quick.  Other than changing the main ingredient in the dish, I felt the need to omit the dried parsley, which might as well be hay for the flavour it has to me, and instead add chopped fresh parsley to the butter after cooking the garlic in it.  I had no problems with sogginess, but then again, I DID cook it longer than 30 min.  I baked it until golden, and it was both crunchy and juicy.  (When I make this with chicken, I'll be increasing the temperature rather than the cooking time so it doesn't dry out though.)

This is a delicious recipe - I had a family favourite years ago from a Canadian Living magazine that was similar (except you wrapped the flattened chicken around a cheddar cheese rectangle, this one is much simpler). I used panko crumbs for the bread crumbs, Italian seasoning for the oregano, and grated extra cheddar cheese, which I put over the chicken with about 10 minutes remaining. I also baked the chicken at 400 F (for the same time, but the chicken breasts were large), which crisped up the coating. Yummy!

Made this as part of mis7up's Hidden Treasures challenge. This has been in my recipe box since 10, Jan. 2011.  There is a reason this recipe has 1,300+ reviews - it is that good.  The breading of bread crumbs, Parmesan & Cheddar cheeses, parsley, oregano, salt and pepper is a wonderful combination.  I made this as written and used my own bread crumbs.   This is a great "company" recipe with a taste that will not fail.  BAYLOR66 most definately has a winner with this one!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2787858.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a few times now and am finally getting around to reviewing it. Here's my two cents: go easy on the butter. It doesn't sacrifice the recipe at all to use far less than called for. Instead of fresh garlic cloves, I use the minced garlic in a jar. I use 1/2 breadcrumbs and 1/2 panko for a crispier texture and sub out basil for the oregano (not a fan). I prefer buying boneless, skinless thin-sliced breasts to avoid pounding them down. It also results in a quicker baking time (I do 20 min at 400 degrees, or 25 min at 375). Finally, don't bother dirtying a baking dish. Just line a baking sheet with parchment paper for quick and easy cleanup. This chicken pairs well with various side dishes, so it makes a weekday dinner a snap to prepare. This is always a hit with the family, so thank you for the submission!

hokielearning2cook

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my second time making this.  First time was a disaster b/c It came out very soggy and I over did the garlic.  This time I made two adjustments.  1. I didn't pour the remaining butter and garlic on the chicken.  I separated the garlic from the butter and just drizzled the butter over the chicken.  2) I broiled the chicken for at least almost 10 minutes to make it crispy.  Before then the chicken was cooked but the breading was very soggy.  I did both times what others suggested and put the breading on the bottom of the pan, but it still was soggy until I broiled it.  I have been told by my 3 & 5 year old as well as DH that it can be "added to the recipe book" a huge deal in our world.  Once it is there the dish is always fair game and can appear at any time.  Everyone (kids and DH) have to give it a thumbs up before putting it in the book.  I will say that I ranked it only four stars though b/c in my world five stars has to go to something that is out of this world.  And while this is great...I wouldn't say it was out of this world.  But it is definitely something we will add to our chicken options!  Thanks for the recipe!
UPDATE: This still is a HUGE hit in my household.  I probably make it twice a month.  My 4 year old actually asks for seconds!  I've found a trick...if you put a cookie cooling rack inside a cookie pan (jelly roll pan) and then put your chicken on top of the cooling rack, the chicken doesn't get mushy on either side!

Normally, I would never do a negative review when I changed a recipe.  I'm doing this one so that future users will know what NOT to do when making this recipe....  I used Italian bread crumbs but omitted the parsley and oregano.  I also used about a half a teaspoon of salt because other reviewers said it was bland.  Everything else I did as written, and it just was not good.  Way too salty.  Maybe I caked too much stuff on the chicken, I don't know.  Hope this helps avoid future disasters, but I won't be making it again either way.

text:
Yum!  The only alteration is I used colby shredded instead of cheddar because that is what I had.  The secret to getting the breading to stick is to blot the chicken with paper towels before dipping into the garlic sauce.  Also, I had to cook mine a full 45 minutes so make sure to allow enough time!  My sides were ready before the main dish.  Similar to other breaded chicken recipes, but the garlic butter and cheese are a great twist!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Smells delicious while oven frying. :) I definitely recommend the panko for a better crunch.  Also, we found that 1 1/2 cups of cheddar was way too much.  I use about 3/4 of a cup of very sharp cheddar and 1/2 cup of parmesan.  I also dip the chicken in flour before the butter.  It definitely helps to keep the cheese and breading in tact. Since chicken breast is so bland, I mixed salt in with the flour for an extra layer of flavor.  My family really enjoyed this served with buttered noodles and a green leafy salad.

text:
Great for the GARLIC LOVER!!!  My teenage son even loved it!  I used seasoned panko breadcrumbs that gave an extra crispiness.  Also, I found that the butter/garlic mixture was just enough to coat both sides of only 4 halves of chicken breast (lightly pounded).  Next time I'll probably add more to have enough to pour over the top.  Used Italian seasoning because I didn't have any oregano or parsley on hand and one of my favorite kitchen tricks is to use either a microplane or small grater for the garlic rather than trying to mince small. Always looking for something easy with ingredients that are usually on hand...this was great!

text:
Made this recipe last night at my husband's urging. Usually he doesn't care for cheese and chicken, except parmigiana. He asked me to make this. I only had shredded mozzarella cheese and exchanged 1 tblspn of extra virgin olive oil, rather than butter. Never added salt because of health issues. I made it using 6 breasts which were already pretty flat. Used panko whole wheat crumbs. I served it with leftover rice pilaf to which I added about 1 cup of frozen peas, which I steamed for the 30 minutes that the chicken baked. I didn't believe that the chicken would be ready in just 30 minutes, but I found that it was true. Great dish, great leftovers and very easy.

I just made this tonight for dinner.  It was VERY good.  We thought we would have leftovers but there was nothing left!  I didn't have oregano or parsley.  I used pepper, basil, garlic, and salt.  I also used corn flakes with bread and put it in my blender.  I also blended some cheese in with the bread crumb mixture and a couple handfuls of flour.  Then I shredded some cheese to sprinkle on top.  I sprinkled the bottom of the pan with the bread crumb mixture.  I will DEFINITELY be making this again! Our 7 year old devoured it like it was his last meal (and he is SUPER picky). Awesome recipe!

text:
This recipe is made once a week at our house. Its so easy to put together & always tastes great.  We used to stuff the chicken with Mozz. before breading, but now (trying to cook with a toddler in the kitchen) I just sprinkle it on top at the end. It is also easier to melt the butter in the microwave with either halved garlic cloves, or garlic powder. I don't even have to turn on the stove. Line the pan w/ foil & I don't have to clean up either.  Also goes great with the honey roasted potatoes on this site.

text:
This is the 1st time my husband has ever said "I LOVE THIS!" about my cooking. I halved the recipe. Followed someone else's suggestion to sub. olive oil for half of the butter. I put half the cheddar cheese in the bread crumb mix, and the other half sprinkled on top. I also spinkled a little bit of garlic powder on top. I didn't have any parsley so subbed a little more oregano and thyme.

text:
This had a really good flavor. They did not get crispy on their own. I had to transfer them to a cookie sheet, turn the oven up to 400* and bake them on the bottom rack for 5 mins to get them to crispen up on the bottom. I also put more cheese on at the end because the cheese gets very crispy when baked and I wanted a more gooey cheese flavor. Served with fresh boiled broccoli and cheese sauce. Overall a good recipe.

text:
One of my family's favorite ways to make super fast chicken. I made the follow adaptations: Blend Panko and Italian Herbed & Garlic Bread crumbs, Instead of pounding thin, slice chicken breasts in half to thin them out. Cut the Butter in half. Turn the chicken half way through and top with shredded cheddar for last minute instead of mixing it with breadcrumbs. Great melted cheesy topping, with less (only 1/2 cup)

I LOVED THIS!!!!

I have been living in the south of china for almost a year now, and only have access to some of the western ingredients I am used to cooking with. I find it difficult to make meals that my  family will enjoy.....until this!!
This recipe was such a hit with my picky daughter and husband who doesn't like any thing I cook, that they BOTH cleaned their plates!! I didn't change a thing in the recipe and don't think anything needs changing, it is perfect just the way it is.
Thank you so much for this delicious  chicken dish, and the peace of mind from knowing that once a week my family will enjoy at least one meal!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic - super easy to put together and a very tasty result!! I never keep dried parsley so I substituted some italian seasoning. As well, I didn't feel like getting a saucepan out (did these in a toaster oven) just to melt butter so I grated some garlic and put it on a plate with the butter and into the microwave for about 30 seconds. One of the best tips from another poster was to use a food processor to blend the breadcrumbs and cheese together and it worked fabulously. I had a very nice even breadcrumb/cheese coating that stuck well to the chicken.
I also 1/4'd the recipe as there's only 2 of us and I had 2 chicken breasts. This one is going into my recipe book!

text:
I think this could be kicked up a little but my husband who does not like a lot of flavors liked it a lot.  It was one of his most favorite things I have made from this site.  Update to my review - In order to save time I melted butter in a 9x13 glass dish in the oven, put about 5 cloves of garlic, added the chicken, poured the crumbs mixture over the top.  This saved a lot of time and it was really good.  I also added more seasonings to the crumb mixture and with those extra seasonings and the extra garlic in the pan it was very good and smelled great cooking.  No mess either.

More tasty than the Parmesam Chicken everyone is used to. Don't cook over 30 minutes or the cheese will get hard and dry. I just made 1/2 of this recipe using 3 chicken breast, pounded very thin, my husband and I had 1 piece each and 1 piece was left for lunch tomorrow. Will make again, also I made it EXACTLY like recipe is written, otherwise how can you honestly rate it?? Next time I may change things a bit but not telling here!! Great as is!!

userID:

Display Name:
Lili Zimmermann
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6324028.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews, this is what I did: Instead of using 8 chicken breasts, I used 4 big ones and 1 tiny one, which fit in the pan perfectly. I did not scale the other ingredients down except the butter. I only used one stick (1/4 cup) of butter. I crushed up some ritz, saltines and corn flakes and used some dry bread crumbs to make one cup. I dipped the chicken in flour before dipping in the garlic butter. I used an aluminum pan, and sprinkled a generous amount of bread crumbs on the bottom of the pan so that the chicken would not get soggy. (I found that it was hard for the breading mixture to stick to the chicken). I baked it (uncovered) for 50-55 minutes, and it was delicious! The kids loved it, too.

text:
NICE! My husband absolutely loved these! I barely changed a thing!!! First of all, don't FORGET to pound the chicken to even thickness to ensure they get cooked in the same amount of time. **Hint: To pound the chicken--Use plastic wrap, double the size of your cutting board(lengthwise). Then place the chicken in between to avoid unwanted messy splatter.** I used panko crumbs mixed with Italian breadcrumbs for the crust with the other seasonings(omited the dried parsley). I put a little bit of flour(about 1/2 cup) into a ziploc bag with fresh chopped parsley(about a handful) and coated the chicken before the coat of garlic butter. Oh my, it turned out awesome!!!

text:
Loved it! I didn't use any parsley because I don't have it at home, and I seasoned the chicken lightly with Goya Adobo in place of the salt and pepper the recipe calls for. I also used Progresso Panko bread crumps in PLAIN (the oregano & cheeses seasoned the panko bread crumbs.) I used an aluminum pan to bake the chicken and did not end up with a soggy bottom to it. And the panko added a great crunch, so I didn't need to use the broiler setting at the end of cooking time. Will definitely make again! Thanks Baylor66!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is the one I started with, and have been hooked to this site since then. I sometimes pound the chicken thin, but slicing the breasts into thinner pieces (along the entire length) is just as good. The grocery store actually charges extra for thin cut breasts. Without slicing or pounding the breast, it can be so thick you have to overcook it (as to the breadcrumb coating) and you just lose some of this great flavor. I also don't use a 9X13 dish, I use a cookie sheet.  It seems to crisp up better and the breast pieces are not touching. I've passed this on to coworkers who all love this recipe.

text:
I did not like this at all. I gave it two stars only because it was edible (with ketchup.) I love garlic, and I love cheese, but the taste of this dish (what little there was of it) was just not good. The funny thing is I have a chicken nugget recipe that I love that uses almost the exact same ingredients (minus the butter, garlic, and cheese.) Instead of being dipped in garlic butter, though, the chicken is dipped in canola oil. Maybe it was just the combination of butter, garlic, bread crumbs, and cheese that I didn't find palatable. Who knows. The chicken was juicy, though. I didn't pound mine flat, so I cooked them for an hour. I also spinkled some bread crumbs on the bottom of the pan, like others suggested, which kept the bottom from being soggy. I might have liked this chicken better if I hadn't spinkled the remaining breading over the breasts, like the recipe calls for. Too bad I'll never make it again to see if it'd taste better with less breading.

text:
Just a little tip - whenever I make this in a pan or even on a cookie sheet, the bottom gets a little bit gooey.  To make it crispy all the way around, I just put the chicken directly on the oven rack, and place foil on the rack below to catch any crumbs.

text:
This recipe is YUMMY!  Only differentce I made is I put the breadcrumb mixture (less the cheddar) in a ziploc baggie and after dipping the chicken pieces in the garlic butter I threw each one in the baggie and shook it around.  The mixture comes out well-mixed and coats the chicken evenly.  I put the some of the cheddar on top of the chicken before baking and the rest on top a few minutes before serving.

This was yummy!!!    Both my boyfriend and his friend raved about it, (the friend acutally licked his plate!)  I did follow other reviewers suggestions and baked on a foil lined baking sheet and broiled for the last 5 min.  Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. Next time I will make a bit more of the coating.  Over all, a super recipe and I will be making again!!!

This chicken is absolutely fantastic!!!  I was a little leery that the cheddar cheese would be overpowering, and I am not a cheddar cheese fan. It was extremely moist, even with cooking it longer.  I shared the recipe with my mom and she's making it this week as well!  Thanks for an excellent recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Initially we found it lacking in flavor. We felt the recipe certainly had potential. After tweeking the method and ingredients somewhat. We found the flavor we were anticipating. For us, the key is to lightly message freshly crushed garlic (or granulated garlic), salt,pepper and a sprinkle of dry bones rub directly onto the chicken.  Next coat it with flour. Then dipped into the butter/garlic mixture. Our coating is finely crushed croutons combined with the suggested cheese/herb ingredients. We finish it with additional shredded cheddar. The result is a moist and flavorful main dish. We serve this with confidence! With adjustment 5 stars

userID:

Display Name:
falconemomma

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3720247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Need it even quicker?  Melt butter in microwave then add garlic and microwave about 1 min more (70-80% power).  Pour butter mixture into baking pan add chicken and toss to coat.  Mix other ingredients in gallon plastic bag.  I used a combination of shredded cheddar, grated parmesan, and shredded parmesan. Pour half of breadcrumb and cheese mixture over chicken.  Press in.  Turn chicken over and pour remaining crumb cheese mixture on top.  Pat down and bake.  May need additional 5 minutes of cooking time but cleanup is a breeze!

text:
I was having a dinner party and couldn't figure out what kind of protein to make - I was so sick of always making chicken. But when I saw this recipe it sounded wonderful...and it was that and more! My company reacted just as yo usaid they would - there was NOTHING left and they all remarked about the taste and texture. I had 16 people from all different backgrounds and ethnicity, all different ages - all loved it. I did use Italian Bread Crumbs with garlic and herbs, and used sharp shredded cheddar. I didn't have a lot of juices in the pan - as a matter of fact I was worried when it was in the oven cause they looked a little dry while they were baking. But they were perfectly cooked and beond flavorful. A great company pleaser!

Display Name:
Stacy Broyles

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1352219.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight for dinner. I ended up following some suggestions of other reviewers and I also had to make some other changes. I bought bone in breasts on sale so used those. I cooked them at 400 and checked after 52 minutes. Then let them sit with a foil tent for about 10 minutes. Perfectly done. As far as the way I seasoned them...I marinated the breasts in Italian salad dressing for about five hours. Then I dredged them in butter with 1/2 tsp of garlic powder in it. The only variation to the breading is that I used italian style breadcrumbs and used cheap, not freshly grated parmesian cheese. I also sprinkled a tad bit of cheddar cheese on top of the breasts as I pulled them from the oven. The breasts were tender, had a good flavor internally, and the breading was delicious. Everyone loved it...including my two young kids and my in-laws. Thanks for posting the recipe and thanks for all the reviewers. I love getting good ideas from the things you all say.

country:
None
text:
THIS IS A GREAT RECIPE - look forward to making more. I made Garlic Cheddar Chicken with what I had on hand- Italian store brand bread crumbs, Kraft plain old Parmesan cheese and sharp cheddar, and some white cheddar cheese powder I got from My Spice Sage. I couldn't get the mix to ‘stick’ to the breasts very well so with 10 minutes left baking left I sprinkled the reaming on the breasts. What spilled over made crunchy melted pieces that – TASTED great on their own – and these chicken breasts were OMG – wonderful. Look forward to trying again with fancy ‘panko’ bread crumbs!! I looked at the video AFTER making this – I did not pound the breasts thin – that missed action I will make sure I do next time.

text:
It was easy and delicious.  There are only two of us, so I had to reduce the ingredients, but used equal parts parm and cheddar.  I took the advice of one reviewer and used a beaten egg with the garlic instead of butter to coat the chicken and from another reviewer, I used my Bullet processor to mix all the dry ingredients together ~ it worked like a charm.  I sprayed my Pyrex dish and put a layer of the dry ingredients on the bottom before adding the coated chicken.  Will keep this tasty dish in my regular rotation.  Thank you!

text:
Yummy!! Thanks!  This is the most tender oven chicken I have had in years! We live in high desert(4200 ft.) so some of my recipes seem dryer,etc. I had read many of the reviews & took a few suggestions from them too.  I floured the chicken,dipped in butter & garlic & then the dry mix. I had no crumbs so used 99 cent pkg of home style garlic & butter croutons-crushed & sharp cheddar cheese. My pkg of chicken was 2.25 lbs. so I did not have much butter left over to drizzle & just a little of crumb mix--did add what I had & took advice from one reviewer...sprinkled a little extra cheese on for the last 10 minutes. One reviewer complained about the greasy bottoms, but mine were not that way..maybe because of more chicken.  I did notice that the butter was sinking to bottom as dish cooled--my suggestion--lift the pieces out of the baking pan & put them on a raised rack for a little bit. Note: using the garlic & butter croutons that I had on hand gave the dish an extra garlic zing!  I am a taster cook & was checking the chicken to make sure it was done--well, I kept eating that piece of chicken til' it was gone! lol. Thanks for the recipe..I am passing this one on to a few women--who still cook!  ( I am senior citizen & have been cooking & baking since I was 8yrs old.)  The last few years I have not been able to stand so long on kitchen floor to cook & bake...I loved to cook & bake for people who enjoyed my efforts.  I cook in larger amounts now & freeze & heat up leftovers for lat

text:
Made this for dinner last night.  Absolutely scrumptious and husband loved it!  I used 1/2 plain and 1/2 seasoned breadcrumbs.  Also for added crispness, I used another reviewer's suggestion and placed a thin layer of coarsely crushed Texas Toast brand cheddar and garlic croutons at the bottom of the baking dish.   I  used Perdue's thin cut boneless, skinless chicken breasts.  At 350 degrees, it took longer than 30 minutes to cook in my oven so I turned it up to 450 degrees for an additional 15 minutes and then broiled the top for about 3-5 minutes.  Gave it a nice golden brown color and as I said - SCRUMPTIOUS!!

This was pretty dang good.  I did make a few changes based on some other reviews.  I used chicken tenders, put bread crumbs on the bottom of the casserole dish (genius!), use a handful of pizza cheese (had little left in the bag and I wanted to use it up) along with the cheddar cheese, panko bread crumbs instead of regualar bread crumbs, italian seasoning instead of the oregano and parsley (the grinder kind) and some ranch dressing mix.  The kids loved it so I will defintely be making again!

text:
OMG, this was fantastic. I did stray from the original recipe cause I didn't have any bread crumbs, but I did read one review that mentioned using croutons so I used the ones we had  which were "Fresh Gourmet Cheese & Garlic". I also only had 2 pieces of chicken which I did flatten, so I decided to cut the ingredients in half & WOW what an amazing flavor. I read some reviews that said there was not much of a "wake up" to the chicken & I think that they should make it again & just add a little more ingredients. This tastes fantastic. I made it after my wife went to bed so she will be having it for lunch tomorrow & I expect a call around lunch time praising how good this is ;) I will be making this again for sure. Thank You for this wonderful & very tasty recipe.

This recipe was okay. I don't think it was anything special. When I mixed all the ingredients together to make the breading it didn't taste any different than if I bought a packaged breading. I cut the chicken breasts into halves, lengthwise and then crosswise, which made smaller pieces. They baked up juicy and were not dried out. I would make this recipe again but  to me it was a regular, weeknight, baked chicken dish. The title makes is sound tasty but to me it just wasn't that tasty.

text:
Insanely good, and easy.  In addition, I clarified the butter before adding the garlic, which I only cooked for 3 minutes being careful not to burn it....  Also, I doubled or tripled the seasonings, and added Old Bay as well.  Trust me, do that.  As for the bread crumbs, I mixed seasoned (Italian) with Panko (for more crunch).  This is KILLER.  Also, it might not hurt to add some white wine in there, possibly to the baking dish....Sauvignon Blanc just goes with chicken, garlic, and cheese.

CJ

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/518193.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not the biggest chicken fan but my husband really liked this and kept saying "good chicken hon" even eating leftovers the next day.  He brought an extra breast into work and his co-worker really liked it too.  It has a nice garlic flavor and since I always use panko breadcrumbs instead of regular the texture was tender inside and light and crispy on the outside.  I might dip breasts in flour and egg next time because the coating barely stuck to the chicken when dipped in butter.  I basically had to spoon the topping over the chicken and pat it down so it would stay.  I had some really thick chicken breasts and even after pounding they were thicker than I like.  Next time I will pound them more or try cutlets and I think I will like even more.  My 8-year-old liked this as well and when he smelled the minced garlic cooking he couldn't wait to eat!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe!  I had to make a few changes  in an attempt to cut down the fat content.   I used olive oil instead of butter though I did throw a tbsp of butter into the olive oil for taste.  Instead of breadcrumbs, I used herbed stuffing (a personal preference).  I cut way down on the cheese, 1/3 c each.   I followed previous reviewers advice and put a little stuffing on the bottom of the pan.  I also covered the chicken with the leftover stuffing/cheese mix and the olive oil over that.   It was fabulous!  Sure I would have loved more cheese but the flavor was there.

I love it so much I've practically got it memorized so the next time we're at a loss at what to make for dinner, I can get the ingredients to this!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think I died and went to heaven.  Granted, this recipe is deadly in terms of fat and salt, but as far as I'm concerned, I don't care.  My husband was a little worried about the health factor between the cheese and butter so I did cut the butter by about 1/3, but I feel like this recipe was easy, delicious and fulfilling and so you just don't eat it every single day.  Personally I don't worry about salt and fat, so this was perfect for me. I'm not one bit shy to admit that I nearly made a meal out of the crispy greasy bits on the bottom of the baking pan when it came out of the oven.  One serious note, I used thin cut chicken breasts, cooked them for 20 minutes at 350 as the recipe stated and then cranked it up to 450 for 5 minutes and it was perfect.  Also, I didn't use fresh garlic, instead just used some dehydrated garlic cooked in the butter for a minute or so.

text:
The first time I made this my Husband said this was "the best chicken" I'd ever made... and I've made A LOT of chicken over the years!!!  I wouldn't personally call it the end-all, be-all BEST-chicken-ever, but it's soooooo EASY, uses ingredients always on hand, and it is quite good, so I still give it 5 stars.  This is a FANTASTIC weeknight staple around here.  And I use my handy-dandy Martha S. digital meat thermometer and remove it from the oven at 165d... (Depending on how thin you pound it) 30m cook time is usually too long and will result in dry chicken, 22-25m usually works for me.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/461966.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very tasty recipe!  I am giving it a 4 out of 5 stars because I did find the bottom of the chicken got a little soggy and I had some trouble getting the bread crumb mixture with the shredded cheese to stick well to the chicken.  However, I was just reading some of the reviews and see some suggestions to address those issues – such as putting a layer of bread crumb on the bottom of the baking dish to prevent the bottom from getting soggy and also dipping the chicken in flour before the butter mixture to help with the bread crumb mixture sticking better - So I am excited to try this recipe again – taking those suggestions into consideration.  Over-all it tastes great.

text:
My family and I loved this recipe!  There are so many possibilites w/this, its great!  I took the advise of the 1st review and made the 1st 1/2 w/Panko. I made the 2nd 1/2 w/bread crumbs and they were both great!  I also added some garlic salt for a little more flavor.  I also read a review about adding bread crumbs to the bottom of the pan before baking, I thought that was a great idea, but it didn't work out for me, maybe I did something wrong b/c it caused my chicken to burn on the bottom.  The pans that I didn't presprinkle w/bread crumbs turned out better (I doubled the recipe).  No big deal though, it was fantastic all the way around, anyway we made it.  :)  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
These are tasty. However, for health reasons, I had a hard time with all the butter called for. I sauteed the garlic in a bit of olive oil, then pressed the "top" of each breast into the garlic oil before breading. I drizzled just a bit of melted butter on each breast before putting in the oven. I used panko bread crumbs and it had a nice crispy texture. I will make these again, the guys even remarked they liked them! Thank you!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good.  My husband is not too fond of chicken breasts, but he really liked them this way.  They stayed moist and had a great flavor.  I did make a couple of changes based on our tastes and other's suggestions.  I pounded the chicken to make it thinner.  Then I let the pieces marinate in italian dressing for about 1/2 an hour.  Next I dipped the pieces in the butter and garlic (I added more garlic as we are garlic lovers.).  Then I dipped them into the cheese and bread crumb mixture but instead of adding parsley, oregano, pepper and salt, I just added 1 t of Italian seasoning to the mixture.

text:
I only had two breasts to cook tonight so I adjusted the ingredients and decided to cook them on the stove to avoid turning on the oven. Big mistake! The outside burned before the centres were cooked. Next time I will cook them in the oven no matter the portion I'm making. The crust (parts that weren't too badly burned) tasted great, and with some more garlic this would definitely be very good. Worth another try for sure!

text:
Liked it, I’ll probably try again but with a few modifications. I listened to some of the advices I found here and covered the bottom of the baking dish with some bread crumbs, so the chicken wouldn’t stick (thought it was better than foil, because it the foil sticks in the chicken it would be a disaster). Anyway, that worked out perfectly. I just thought the chicken was a bit dry. I seasoned the chicken like I usually do, coated them with all purpose flour, dipped into the melted butter and then coated it with the bread crumb mixture. The chicken tasted great but it was kinda dry. I don’t know, maybe I’ll try to brine it the next time, maybe it will help. I’ll either do that or bake it with tiny slices of butter in the baking dish (like I saw in another chicken recipe here).

userID:

Display Name:
B_32

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/17.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed almost to a T. I didn't have plain bread crumbs so used Italian seasoned crumbs (omitted the parsley because the crumbs already contain it).  I also used the tip of another reviewer to run the crumb mixture through a food processor so it coats better (highly recommend this step).  I didn't bother pounding the chicken as I knew that leaving them whole would still produce juicy chicken (with the oil from the butter and cheese). Just ensure to extend the cooking time (I cooked mine for 50 minutes - had thick breasts).  This is really good and melt in your mouth, very attractive looking.  Having said that, I think I like "Butter Chicken" (another recipe on this site) a little better as it is the same idea but less work.  The cheddar taste was not as pronounced as I thought (which turned out to be a plus for my kids as they're not really a fan of melted cheese).  I would make this again and for company.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This dish was absolutely delicious. My entire family raved about the different flavors the chicken produced. The only difference was adding 1.5 times the amount of garlic and parm cheese, and it worked out great. After I coated the chicken with the breading, I poured the remaining butter and garlic, and then sprinkled some of the cheese breading on top. Came out perfect. I did have to melt another 1/2 cup of butter, however, for the second coating. The only change I'll make next time is I'll take the advice of another reviewer and coat the pan with breadcrumbs before baking. The bottom of the chicken was a little soggy.

text:
WOW!! This is tasty, easy and fabulous!! I did not pound the chicken breasts, so it took about 40-45 minutes to bake at 375 (I cooked at a higher temperature than stated). I also used Italian bread crumbs so I omitted the parsley and oregano. I followed another reviewers suggestion of putting bread crumbs on the bottom of the pan to help with sogginess. This is a  superb chicken dish. I served it with Jamie's Cranberry Spinach Salad also from this web site.

text:
This was a really good chicken dish.  I used 3 large breasts and did not pound thin.  Used a shredded cheese blend and probably double the garlic.  I think I added too much of the left over coating on top of the chicken after putting in the dish because the topping was a tad too rich/much.  The taste is great though and the chicken was really moist which is a huge plus and one reason why I didn't pound them.  My husband loved them and my 8yr.old son thought it was ok but he doesn't like chicken to begin with so I guess even eating any of it was success for him.  I hadn't taken anything out for dinner and when we got home late from a b-ball game I whipped this up in a jiffy, it's a great last minute meal!  I made the "screaming potatoes" from this site with this and I reviewed that recipe as well along with asparagus.

This was great....another winner to add to my growing collection.  Made is just the way it's written, except cut in half, and only used 2 breast. Will also experiment with other types of cheese.  Oh yea, I forgot the garlic,(duh), but it was still awesome.

text:
I just have to review this one again. This is a family favorite...incredibly moist, perfect every time.  Make sure you really drench the chicken in the butter mixture and the crumbs will stick beautifully - don't skimp on the butter.  It's so tender you may not think it's cooked at first, but 30 min. always works perfectly for me.  If you want, broil on low last 3-5 minutes (watch closely).  With all the butter, never sticks to my pans...easy cleanup.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mixed reviews at our house.  My daughter just LOVED this dish!  However, my husband and son were not impressed at all.  This was super easy & fast to prepare, and it smelled wonderful while baking.  The chicken was sooo tender and moist, and the topping was delicious.  But, even for a serious garlic lover like me, it was too intense, and too salty.  The garlic permeated from me for nearly 2 days after eating this.  I enjoyed it, but I'd probably recommend the following changes:  1) Cut the garlic down to 2 cloves, 2) Eliminate the salt altogether as the parmesan is naturally salty enough,  and 3) Replace half of the butter w/ olive oil to elimate some of the saturated fat.

text:
I made this tonight but since my family is small I cut the recipe in 1/2 and it turned out great. The only thing I did different was I left out the shredded cheddar cheese and just sprinkled it on top. covered it and baked at 350' for 40 minutes. I was surprised at how much flavor this had. I wasn't really expecting that but we all loved it. Even my toddler did and you know how picky kids can be! Thanks for sharing. I plan to make this again.

text:
This is a delicious dish and an easy recipe to follow. The first time I made this, I knew it was a keeper because my husband wanted leftovers to take to work the next day, and he never before would eat leftovers.  I've also made this dish with some minor changes, and it was very good that way, also. Instead of Parmesan alone, I used Parmesan/Romano grated cheese.  I also substituted shredded Colby/Jack for the cheddar cheese.  Finally, I used Italian flavored bread crumbs. If you've ever been to Leona's (in Chicagoland), this is very similar to their Romano Crusted Chicken. Wonderful!

text:
Really delicious. I needed about 45 minutes to get the chicken cooked though. Instead of breadcrumbs, I used crushed reduced fat ritz, and I used reduced fat margarine instead of butter. Although I had only 4 chicken breast halves, they were very large, so I used all the same spices, but eyeballed the amounts, using 3 garlic cloves. I used closer to a full cup of cheddar cheese and 1/3 cup Parmesan. We ate this with mashed potatoes and it turned out great. Loses a little something reheated in the microwave the next day, but it's stil good.

text:
My husband thought they were very good.  I thought it was to much cheddar cheese.  I peeled off the breading and the flavor was excellent.  One stick of butter wouldn't do 8 breasts.  I cut up 3 large ones and pounded them thin and there might have been a Tablespoon left.  They baked in 30 min.  The food processor saved a lot of time.  I think it took longer than 15 min. to put together.  After I grated the cheese I put the breadcrumbs back in the processor with the cheese and processed it more to combine all ingredients.  I will fix this again and use less cheese.

Delicious! I made some changes based on other reviews: I floured then buttered; spread bread crumb mixture in the bottom of the dish; I had large cheese shreds so I topped the chicken off just before baking. The chicken was very tender and had that wonderful cheesy crunch - will definitely make this again!

text:
I used panko instead of regular bread crumbs but otherwise followed the instructions exactly. It turned out great and I will definitely keep this recipe in my rotation. I cooked on parchment and had no problems with sogginess or sticking, probably because the panko tends to stay crisper than standard bread crumbs. I think this would also be good with mozzarella instead of cheddar as a base for chicken parmesan. Thanks!

text:
Made this exactly as the recipe suggested and it was so good! My kids all loved it too. We will be having this regularly. My only suggestion would be to add the remaining breadcrumb mix to the top but not the leftover butter. It was a bit greasy on the bottom due to the butter from the chicken and the cheeses. Had I not used the leftover butter, I'm sure it would have been perfect. 

It got a parmesan crust on the edges of the pan that you will want to scrape off and eat. Don't waste that deliciousness!!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4885492.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this chicken with only minor changes - used Panko instead of bread crumbs; grated pecorino romano cheese instead of parmesan (had it on hand).  Followed reviewers' suggestions to dip chicken in flour before the butter; put thin layer of crumbs at bottom of  dish; minced ingredients in blender.  The chicken browned beautifully (no need to put under broiler).  Here's where I had a brain drain.  Checked temp of chicken at 30 minutes before removing. 
 It was only 85 degrees!!!  Completely panicked.  A reviewer had advised to turn the chicken over at 20 minutes.  I thought maybe that was the problem.  Flipped chicken - what a mess!!!  Do NOT flip - there's absolutely no need  and it ruins the breading.  Put the chicken back in the oven - then it occurred to me to make sure that the thermometer was set on Fahrenheit (which it normally is).  Sure enough it was on Centigrade (have no idea how that happened).  Re-checked temperature and it was done!!!! Oh well....  The flavor was good, but very mild.  I will definitely make this again but may add some crushed red pepper.  Very nice and easy recipe.  Thanks for posting.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made this several times now, make sure you use grated parm - like the stuff in the green jar- or it won’t stick very well. First time I made it I followed the recipe, but used the wrong parm. It was a bit of a soggy mess but tasted ok. I’ve started using Panko and it comes out crispier. I also just use chicken tenderloins now, perfect size for these. Also, don’t pour the extra garlic butter over the chicken, that was how I ended up with a soggy mess.

text:
YUUUUUUUUM!!!!!!!!!
If I could give this ten stars, I would!!! So easy, so delicious, so perfect! I have a picky boyfriend that doesn't like much of anything and he LOVED this!! I made a few changes....
1. I sprinkled some breading on the pan before laying the chicken on it.
2. I flipped the chicken half way through to make sure it was browned on both sides. And
3. I didn't poor the extra garlic butter on top of the chicken, it would have been too much garlic.
Make this, you'll LOVE it!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy.  Very tasty.  Chicken was very moist.  I made only minor changes.  Melted less butter than stated and used roasted garlic rather than regular, in a small shallow fry pan.  My chicken breasts were very large so I cut them in half before pounding.  I dipped them into the pan with melted butter rather than pouring that into a shallow bowl. Used panko as I was out of bread crumbs. Reducing the amount of butter resulted in not having soggy breading and the chicken did not stick to my pyrex plate.  Thank you for the video that showed using tongs to handle the chicken breasts.  I've done the one handed dips and breading before but this is so much less messy!

text:
This was a good recipe that was husband approved! If you are looking to lighten the carbs or make this indulgent meal a little kinder to your blood sugar, substitute the bread crumbs for almond flour like I did. It created a beautiful, nutty flavor and kept the breading-like texture, but doesn't have all of the extra carbs that come alone with breadcrumbs.

country:
None
text:
I've made this multiple times, and I could never figure out how to get both sides of the chicken to come out crispy, since my wife is rather picky about texture. If any of you have the same trouble, go with this solution that I came up with tonight. Bake in the oven at the directed temp for 25 minutes. Then flip the pieces over, you may need to coat the other side of each piece, and cook for an additional 5 minutes. Worked like a charm. And my wife liked it!

I added about 6-7 cloves of minced garlic, alot more than recommended, but my family loves garlic so it was good! didnt have shredded parmesan so i used the powdered version (that you usually sprinkle on top of pastas) instead. still turned out amazing! 
NOTE: remember to COAT the bottom of the pan with the remainder of the breadcrumb/cheese mixture so that the bottom of the chicken gets flavour too. brush the pan with olive oil first before doing this, if not the cheese mixture will burn and stick onto the baking pan.

Display Name:
Hannah Ulrich

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3699359.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this four times, each time a little different. The version I liked best, I had 1.5 times the amount of bread crumbs, half the amount of Parmesan, and 1.5 times the amount of Cheddar.  This made it much crispier and crunchy on top.  I also doubled the amount of parsley and oregano and didn't put any salt in. I also mini-marinated the chicken in the garlic butter, submerging one piece in the garlic-butter mixture (off the burner)  for about 4-5 minutes before rolling it in the crumbs.  Like some other reviews, I put a layer of bread crumbs on the bottom of the pan, then the chicken, then extra garlic butter, and then more crumbs. This made the chicken much more tender and the coating more crunchy.  Enjoy!!!
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2017-04-05T23:44:45.01
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
21405023
Display Name:
kperri
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0

favoritesCount:
99
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Making this as we speak. Giving an average rating for two reasons- I didn't make it as written, but there are definitely flaws in the written recipe/method. As far as ingredient modifications I added fresh basil and parsley to the bread crumb mix and used all Parmesan (fresh) since I'm going for a chicken parm sorta deal. I had thrown all my chicken breasts into Italian dressing yesterday before deciding what to do with them so they ended up being marinated. Heres why I'm writing a review-- if you don't put your chicken onto a rack to bake as stated in some reviews it will have a soggy coating. Some are fine with this, I am not. I tried baking it as instructed but checked on it half way through to check on it. The top was okay but not crisp yet and the bottom was very soggy and sitting in a pool of oil. This is how I fixed it- broiled for three minutes to make sure top side was crisped, removed breasts from the pan drained the excess oil laid down a layer of bread crumbs and placed the breasts back in crispy side down, sprinkle just a little fresh crumbs on top and back in the oven for second half. Will broil this side as well at the end. Just wanted to share in case anyone else goes with the recipe as written and needs a quick fix.

text:
It was good, but it does require tweaking. Cut breasts into thirds. Don't pound the chicken. Cook it for 50 minutes. I also added more cheddar to the top of the meal, after 30 min. While it was tasty, I found it to be a little bland. You can easily  sprinkle the chicken with your favorite spice, like chili powder or lemon pepper, after the butter treatment, and before you coat it with other ingredients. Make it to your specs for a great meal. I sprinkled it with a little lemon pepper, after cooking, and that gave it more flavor.

Excellent!! Dish I tweaked the recipe  a little, instead of pounding the breasts, I cut the 2 whole breasts into 4, I then forked the chicken and added my own blend of seasoning, rubbing it into the chicken before dipping into the melted butter garlic mixture I added onions to the butter garlic as well, instead of cheddar I used a Mexican blend, Asiago, Asero, Cheddar and parmesan and it came out to die for, I believe you lose tenderness and juices pounding it , my opinion of course

text:
Very good! And easy to make, even for me. I took some suggestions: panko for breadcrumbs, thin layer of breading on pan beneath chicken, cheddar cheese on top, and broiled on high for 2 mins after baking. Next time I'm going to make a lot more of the breading mix so I can better layer the pan. Another time I'll try to play with how/when to add the cheddar cheese as I feel having it create a crust on top kept the breading from having a crunch. Still a fantastic recipe!

text:
I thought it was really good, an easy quick chicken recipe. I boiled the chicken first because it was frozen, and the meat fell right off the bones. It was perfect! I used a bag of club crackers in replace of bread crumbs and it was phenomenal. I also added red chili flakes to the herbal mixture for an added zing, I used just regular pizza parmasean because that's all I had and it all came out amazing. Cook time was about 15mins. Or less because it was more about melting the ingredients and bringing the flavors together. Pulled it out, drizzled a little bit more butter over the top, put foil over the top of the tray to rehydrate with steam for about 2 mintues, and devoured it. Definitely will make this again.

userID:
9926480
Display Name:
Medic1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
23
favoritesCount:
255
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't usually alter a recipe until I've tried it as written, but I've learned to read the reviews and listen to the ones that are repeated over and over or at least sound right. So I altered this one and it came out very good. The kids and my grandmother loved it. My grandmother said it was the best chicken she's ever eaten. The wife and I thought it was pretty good. Here's what I did:

Definitely flatten the chicken. It makes it very tender. I used crushed Ritz crackers for the crumbs because that's what I had on hand. I used Sargentos 4 State Cheddar because it's awesome. The cheese was coarsely shredded, so I put the entire breeding mixture in the food processor to make it stick to the chicken better. I coated the chicken pieces in flour before dredging them in the butter. I also lined the bottom of the baking dish with fine cracker crumbs. Finally, I broiled the chicken for two minutes at the end. 

I don't understand why some say the dish has no flavor because there is plenty of flavor in there. It's cheesy and goes well with a side of broccoli.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-04-06T06:40:25.41

text:
Turned out amazing! I used chicken thighs instead of breast since that was what I had on hand. Also, not a fan of cheddar so I used the mexican blend of cheese (again, what was at hand). Positively delicious! Had one piece but really struggling to not go for two more! YUM!

Suggestion: Definitely try out what you like. I love garlic flavors so I added more garlic. I love the Italian style breadcrumbs so I used those. Also LOVE the flavors of oregano and parsley so I pretty much doubled on that. I leave out the salt since I think I've got that covered with all the other ingredients. I need my food bursting with flavor! Next time I might add a bit of cayenne pepper just to see the outcome!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good chicken! I make this when I need to put something together quickly by using garlic powder (about a teaspoon) instead of fresh garlic, and seasoned bread crumbs. I use Smart Balance spread instead of the butter, and omit the salt in the coating mix. I also leave out the Cheddar cheese and sprinkle it on top of my coated chicken instead. I can cut down on the cheese this way, and using reduced fat cheese cut down more fat and calories.  Makes a good dinner with a green salad and whole wheat rolls.

text:
This was excellent -- quite tasty.  I followed the instructions pretty closely, with the exception that I went light on the cheese and subbed mozzarella for some of the cheddar.  Also, I was a bit heavy-handed with the garlic (no stars take away for that). 

A couple thoughts:  
* I strongly agree with the suggestion to go with Panko bread crumbs as well.  They were crispy in a way that's hard to attain with regular bread crumbs -- especially those from a package. 
* I'd like to try this with less butter next time. It was delicious, but I think I'll give it a shot with olive oil and a little butter, just to make it a bit healthier.

None
text:
Amazingly simple and delicious recipe! We ratcheted up the flavor by replacing the bread crumbs/oregano/parsley with the Savory Herb flavor of Stovetop. Also, be warned that pouring all the butter on top of the chicken, depending on your tastes, may be too much. The first time we made this we poured all the butter on and it was simply too rich; I could feel my arteries clogging as I chowed down! Pouring out about half of the remaining butter seems to strike a good balance between moisture, flavor, and keeping it from being too "rich"

country:

text:
This is a perfect recipe. I am obsessed with it. But I did make a few changes to my recipe. I didnt add the parmesan because the cheddar to me was more than enough. I just used italian seasoning because it has all the herbs wrapped into one, and I didnt put salt because the cheddar and butter are already salted. And when it was almost done cooking (maybe 5 more minutes needed) I tasted it and for some reason my taste buds told me it needed lemon. So I said to myself, if I squeeze lemon, the breading is going to get all clumpy and weird, so I sprinkled some organic lemon pepper and OMG it gave it such a wonderful kick.  Other than that, I followd the recipe and honestly, I want to make more but I ran out of italian bread crumbs. My toddlers,  My son who is almost 3 and my daughter wo is a month shy of being 2 are pretty picky, My daughter who wants nothing to do with meat or chicken, devoured it and I steamed some brocolli along to mix in to kill two birds with one stone, and my son, who is the pickiest eater ever, devored this as well and I would sneak in a florlet of brocolli or two and he wouldnt notice. He kept telling me, "more chicken, more taste". LOL. I am a stay at home mom and literally besides picking up after them, I spend my day in the kitchen trying to make things that will satisfy their little tummies. This did it for them and me.

text:
I tip my hat to the creator of this recipe! It is my husbands favorite meal. We were out of breadcrumbs the first time I made this so the only ingredient adjustment I ever did (and still do) was to use matzo meal instead of breadcrumbs. It came out wonderful and so flavorful! I also usually make a cooking preparation adjustment due to disliking having the stove top on since I have a very grabby eight month old son! I melt the butter in the microwave and use a half teaspoon of garlic powder instead of the clove garlic. It's almost the same result as the original recipe, although I don't think powdered spices are ever as good as fresh. Thank you for this recipe!

Delicious recipe. The cheddar cheese was an interesting addition and made a nice crust on the chicken. I didn't have fresh garlic so I used granulated, but I'm sure fresh would be better. Using the melted butter didn't really make the crumbs stick, but it didn't matter, I just sprinkled it on top of the chicken after placing them on a foil lined cookie sheet. A tip: spray the foil! I thought the butter was enough to keep it from sticking, but it should have been sprayed with pam first.

None
text:
YUM! I added an egg to the butter to help the coating stick (just make sure the butter isn't too hot so the egg doesn't scramble!). I also baked an additional 15 minutes and turned the heat up to 400 for that period to allow the cheese to get a bit brown/crispy. This is a keeper, leftovers are great right out of the fridge! Do make sure to use plenty of non-stick spray and/or nonstick aluminum foil, they will stick quite a bit without!

userID:
558228
Display Name:
R. J. Nequette
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

72
favoritesCount:
397
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1037338.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so moist and tasty.  I didn't change any ingredients but did change the method only a little.  My chicken breasts were really huge so I cut them in half horizontally before they were completely thawed (really easy then).  Added a little garlic powder and pepper right onto the chicken before coating with garlic butter/evoo and dry mix.  I used my mini food processor for the dry mix to crumble all finer. I lined a cookie pan with foil and topped with a cooling rack.  Cooked on the rack for 35 minutes turning at the 15 minute mark, then broiled for 2 minutes to crisp the top. Perfect. My husband just kept raving about it.  This is now my favorite baked chicken even though I found it time consuming - I am not a fast prepper.  Will definitely make this again.  Thanks

5

userID:
11553529
Display Name:
nikkiL
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So, after reading some of the reviews I noticed that the most common issue with this recipe is that it was "bland". So for mine I did quite a few changes on it. I flattened out the chicken breasts and then tossed them in a freezer bag with a yummy Italian dressing and plenty of minced garlic. As for the breading I used a combination of Italian bread crumbs and panko. As for the added ingredients, I went with, oregano, pepper, season salt, garlic powder, parsley, and red pepper to really jazz it up. I dipped the breasts in egg yolk and then in the bread crumb mixture covering the bottom of the pan in the remaining crumbs. I broiled them for the last 5 minutes, once they were beginning to turn gold I tossed the cheddar and parmesan on top they came out flavorful and perfect! My husband and my 4 year old loved it!

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1135378.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really amazing baked chicken recipe. Changes were made for crispier chicken. I slightly took down the amount of butter used here because I skipped the additional drizzling before baking step. I suspect it in being the reason why some other reviewers reported a soggy result. Panko crumbs are definitely a must for a crisp chicken.
Plain parmesan cheese worked really well here as well. I slightly increased the salt in the breading mix. The last 2 minutes of cooking, broil until you get a slightly browned surface. Sliced fresh basil pairs with this recipe perfectly. My husband loved this recipe so I will definitely be keeping this one. 5 stars…

5

This was pretty good. I took another reviewer's advise and cooked the chicken on a foil-lined cookie sheet instead of a baking dish. The breading mixture was delicious and the chicken was very moist.

Very good recipe, however, I added crushed potato chips to the bread crumb mix & cut out the salt. text:
My 13 year old is a chicken breast fanatic, so I'm always looking for new ways to cook them. This was easy, tasty, and used ingredients that I always have on-hand anyway!  I used a heaping teaspoon of Italian seasoning instead of just the oregano, and I only had dried parmesan cheese, but these were my only substitutions.  30 minutes in the oven was the perfect amount of time.  They were flavorful and moist with a crunchy layer on top.  I lined my pan with parchment paper for an easy cleanup.  Will make again.  Thank you.  ;-)

country:
None
text:
This recipe is the best recipe I have found but I will say I added a few changes.  I tried to make it  a bit lower in sodium then what the recipe calls for.  I used unsalted pretzels and ground them up in place of the bread crumbs.  I also added white cheddar and parmesan cheese (I think the yellow cheddar gets too greasy)  I then added for the green element chives instead of oregano and parsley.  The cheese is salty enough that you dont need to add extra salt.  My husband and everyone we have served this too have fought for the final piece!  There are never left overs this way!

Turned out wonderful!! I used 3 breasts & cut into about 4 pieces each. I did not have garlic cloves, so just mixed garlic powder with the butter on the stove top. I also crumbled up some cheez-it's in the bowl. Next time I will put a cheese layer on the bottom of the pan, but I poured the extra butter & cheese on top & it turned out delicious. I baked for 17 minutes, broiled for 3 (should have done just 2) and then baked another 3. Delicious & super juicy!!

I absolutely love this recipe.  I have made this more than half a dozen times and everyone who tries it falls in love with the flavors and tenderness of the chicken.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.  The one thing I found was that using shredded cheddar can be a bit difficult and it is best to use fancy shredded cheddar so that the shreds are smaller and stick to the chicken better.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I forgot to pound the chicken breasts but it still turned out great. I added a little olive oil to the butter mixture and sauteed the garlic for just a minute or two - five minutes is too much for fresh garlic. Then I just pressed the coating into the chicken, poured the leftover sauteed garlic butter over the chicken, and baked it a tad longer than the recipe - maybe 35-40 minutes as they were plump breasts. My oven runs a little cold so I jacked up the heat to 400 for the last ten minutes or so to brown. Very fast and easy to scale - I made it for just two breasts, but going to try four tonight!

country:
None
text:
If you want a great recipe that everyone will love try this.  I make this about every 1-2 weeks and the family loves it.  I just use Panko crumbs and shredded cheddar of choice and the parmesan cheese. The trick to making it great is when you dredge it in the garlic butter... make sure you get both sides covered well. My only change was cooking time... I went a little higher setting 400-425 for a good 20 mins and maybe a little longer, just monitor cooking time.  If you compare this to the "KRAFT Fresh Take"... this wins hands down.
Very good...   : )

text:
We all liked this, although I would have liked the breading to be more crispy (not sure if that's possible when you bake a breading vs. deep frying). I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs since that's what I had on hand (about 10). I used the Italian breadcrumbs and a Mexican blend shredded cheese plus some additional spices (you can eyeball the crust mixture). The chicken was really moist (although a little over done at 30 minutes). I think the garlic butter is key in this recipe.

text:
I followed the recipe to the letter, and the parts of the chicken that the breading STAYED on was delicious. However, most of the breading stayed on the bottom of the pan, so it was plain chicken breast that you tasted.

If I were to make this again, I would definitely add an egg wash to help the breading stick, and then I am sure it would be much better - the chicken was nice and moist, but I want more than just plain chicken.

That said, also line the pan in foil - it was a pain to clean!

country:
None
text:
A very rich, delicious and classic chicken recipe. The butter and cheese make it so rich, even though it tastes heavenly I could never eat more than one. My advice would be cook what you need for that meal, and no more. I don't believe the bread crumbs would reheat well and this is probably best served as a treat rather than as a regular dish. I cut the servings down to 2, per another reviewer, and the measurements worked perfect. Another reviewer also suggested lightly lining the bottom of the pan with breadcrumbs to keep the chicken from becoming soggy; I thought that worked well also.

text:
I like the ease of this recipe, but so much butter is out of the question for health reasons. I used a mixture of egg beaters & spices instead of butter. I used panko crumbs &added onion powder. I also borrowed the idea of another reviewer to put a layer of bread crumbs on the bottom. Also I sprayed the tops with cooking spray to moisten them to help browning. Result was very tasty, chicken was tender & the coating was crunchy & tasty.

text:
My family gave this a 4.5 star rating (5 stars being Pizza, of which nothing tops...yet).  I am not a cook, I only do it as it's a necessary part of life. I try to find the easiest recipes I can that will take the least amount of time, this was both.  On top of it being super easy and quick, it was delicious.  I added a tad more butter and a generous amount of garlic beyond what it called for as I was beginning to run low towards the end, but that's the only "problem" (if that could be counted as a problem) that I ran across.  The chicken cooked perfectly, not tough or undercooked at all.  We agreed that this will appear again at the table and I might even take it to a pot luck (of which I usually only sign up for desserts).  A must try for sure.

country:
None
text:
This was easy and delicious. It was simple to pull together for a week night meal!I took a few hints from other reviewers. Using the food processor to combine the ingredients was genius. It made everything uniform size and distributed the flavors evenly over the chicken. It is a good idea to pound the chicken out  because even pounded out.. it really plumps in the oven. As a result it's very juicy! Bread crumbs underneath  did keep it from getting soggy. Used the aluminum pan also. Excellent results!

text:
Did as others recommended and put a thin layer of bread crumbs in my pan, next time I will NOT do this. The breading was far too thick on the bottom. I did not dump the rest of the butter on top, that's insanity lol, so I just drizzled a little with a spoon. The only thing I changed was used a Mexican blend shredded cheese instead of straight cheddar because that's what I had on hand. Was very yummy with the broccoli Alfredo pasta side I made with it. Super easy!

This is the first breaded recipe I have found where there was actually enough breading!

text:
We LOVED this! I did a couple of substitutions. I didn't have any dry bread crumbs, so I used Parmesan Garlic Cheese-Its crushed.  I only had 1/4 c. Parmesan, so I added 1/4 c. Shredded fresh Locatelli Romano Cheese. I also only used 4 chicken breast halves, pounded. I had some trouble getting the dry mixture to stick to the butter soaked chicken, so I ended up just pouring it it over the top to finish it off.

Mmmmm.... so yummy!

None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I wanted to make sure I got a crust, so I first dipped my chicken breasts (not pounded flat) in egg/water, then the bread crumb mixture (to which I added garlic powder and montreal steak seasoning) without the cheddar cheese. I then browned the chicken in the pan with the garlic and butter before popping it in the oven for 30 minutes. After 30 minutes I topped the chicken with the cheddar and baked for another 15 minutes so it would melt. Divine with green beans and mashed potatoes.

text:
This recipe seemed easy enough, so I decided to give it a try for my boyfriend and I. It was delicious!! The only thing I did differently was add a quarter cup of italian dressing to the butter and garlic before dipping the chicken. I then baked them for 30 minutes, drizzled with italian dressing, and left them in the oven (turned off) for 10 more minutes. It was soo good, and my picky boyfriend LOVED it.

text:
This was a delicious recipe! I made two slight changes....Frist I used Panko crumbs in place of the bread crumbs as I LOVE their crunchiness! Secondly, I didn't put the Cheddar in the crumb mix....I was out and my hubby wasn't home in time with it, si I just added grated cheedar on top on each breast for the last 10 minutes of the backing time.  I did find that it took longer to cook, so for the last 10 minutes I bump the over temperature up to 400F. Hope you enjoy it as much as my family did! (Three kids ages 11,8 and 6)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this a few nights ago for dinner and my family loved it. I did do a few things different. First I used 3 large bonless skinless chicken breast and didn't pound them flat. Second I didn't melt the butter and garlic i just used some garlic butter I got from the store and just coated the chicken with that (I figured the bread crumbs would stick better and they did). I also used mozzarella cheese because that is what I had. I then baked the chicken about 20 mins then flipped it over so the bottem could get golden and wouldn't bet soggy( we hate soggy food). It turned out prefect!! I am planning on making this again and this time I want to use the cheddar cheese.
