city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After making this a few more times I've made some changes.  I don't use nearly as much butter, and often substitute olive oil.  I also add some other seasonings and use crushed seasoned croutons.  Adding more cheese towards the end of cooking really helps too, especially if it's a sharp cheddar.  I may try this with fish as well.

This was a great simple recipe.  Everyone in my family loved it, including my 2.5 year old.  We did reduce the butter and used flavored croutons.  I think next time we might add more cheese on top part way through the cooking. It's not very complex for flavors, but you can make up for that with a flavorful side.  I think the simple flavors work well though.  We served it with scalloped potatoes and it was a great meal.

text:
We've made this recipe several times now and LOVE it!  We did make a few changes, however.  I use about 1/2 as much butter and only 2 cloves garlic.  Also, instead of bread crumbs I use crushed seasoned croutons; it gives a much heartier crunch.  I throw in some Montreal Chicken Seasoning OR Crushed Red Pepper to add a bit of a kick.  Definitely a good recipe that has become a staple in our home!  Thanks!!

text:
I enjoyed this chicken. For a cheese lover like me it was a nice change of pace from the usual Parmesan cheese alone. I used nuggets sized chicken breasts which were pre-marinated in a mix of herbs to make these. The chicken came out moist and very flavourful and I enjoyed the coating very much! I did use Italian breadcrumbs cause that's what I had on hand and left out the dried herbs because of this. I also melted some extra butter and drizzled it over the top before baking. I will make this again. Thanks for sharing!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
very good recipe; the garlic in the butter makes a big difference; don't skip it, and PLEASE use the real deal. The tip to put a thin layer of breadcrumbs worked well to keep the bottoms crispy. And the panko crumbs truly do work to crisp up the final products. Here's a tip for the beginning (or lazy) cooks: you may do this recipe and not pound the breasts; just cook them for an hour rather than the stated 30 minutes, and they'll come out the same. The reason to pound is to keep the meat cooked uniformly, so you may find that the thinnest eand of the breasts are too dry if you don't pound them.

text:
This is a staple in our house, for the past few years I've made it at least 1x a month.  I normally put the butter and garlic in my small cast iron pot in the oven while it's preheating and it combines the flavors nicely while I prepare everything else.  I like a really crunchy crust so I mix in crushed garlic cheddar croutons for 1/2 of the amount of bread crumbs.  Thank you for posting it!

text:
This went over very well with everyone I made it for the other night! Even my ridiculously picky husband - who gave it a skeptical look when I was initially mixing all the ingredients together - who found he actually really liked it. 
I made a couple small changes... more or less just with the preparation method. I cut the amount of butter down to half, and didn't even end up using all of it. I brushed the breasts with the melted butter, sprinkled it with garlic powder, salt, pepper and oregano, added 2 tb shredded cheddar and 1 tb shredded parm on each breast, crumbled two ritz crackers over each (instead of bread crumbs) and garnished with parsley.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! Took some commentor's advice and covered the bottom of my casserole dish with crushed croutons to keep the bottom crispy, and it worked great! I adjusted the recipe to feed my family of 4,but found that 6 rather than 2 cloves of garlic fitted better. I also added some crushed cornflakes into my breading mixture, and that was a nice addition. I found it only took 18 minutes to bake, so don't take the recipe's recommendation! I did however broil it for 2 minutes afterwards, based on one commentor's advice, and it got more brown than I would have liked. So be careful! I don't think broiling is really necessary... it's crispy enough without it I'm sure! Everyone kept raving about this chicken all night. Ooooh, and it smelt GREAT while I was cooking it! Great served with a simple iceberg lettuce salad :)

userID:
572250
Display Name:
Raoulysgirl
isPro:

followersCount:
17

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/169126.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ehh...I'm on the fence with this one.  It's a good idea, but I think it gets lost somewhere in translation.  I made a few minor changes, but nothing that would really have much effect on the recipe.  I used seasoned bread crumbs and cut out the seasoning listed in the recipe.  I also stuck my cheese in the freezer for a little bit, then threw it in the food processor to make it a little finer to maybe help with the "getting it to stick" issues.  I took the advice of some of the others and baked on a bed of breadcrumbs.  The resulting chicken was not quite what I was expecting it to be.  I think that I prefer cracker crumbs to bread crumbs when breading chicken for baking.  They don't seem to stay as gritty (?) or something.  If I try this again, I think I will use crushed up Ritz instead of the breadcrumbs.  The flavor was ok, but I didn't really get much of a cheese flavor.  I don't know...this just wasn't what I was expecting.  I don't think I'll make it again, unless I do just to try it with the Ritz.  Thanks for the post, though!

text:
This is a very good recipe but because of the changes i made i only gave it 4 stars. Change 1: melt butter in microwave & add garlic powder instead of garlic cloves to the bread crumb mix. change 2: use Italina bread crumbs already have the ingredient.
change 3: put bread crumb mix into Lg baggie and dip pieces of chicken (i used chicken strips) in butter then shake in baggie till coated.Sprinkle baking dish w/dry bread crumbs after spraying w/olive oil(another members idea) add chicken & top with the rest of the dry bread crumb mix & any left over butter.Bake according to directions & you'll have crispy chicken (no need to broil).I served these with a blue cheese dressing but you could you ranch.ENJOY!

I made this tonight and used 1/2 butter, 1/2 olive oil.  I also used 1/2 breadcrumbs, 1/2 quick oats (I do that in a lot of recipes).  At the end I put it under the broiler for 2 or 3 minutes to crunch the top.  I should have turned it over since the bottom was a little soggy.  Overall a DELICIOUS dish and I will definitely make this again!

text:
What a great idea for boring old chicken.  I scaled down the recipe for 2 rather large chicken breasts and in place of the plain bread crumbs and seasonings I used Italian bread crumbs with some garlic powder.  My 5-year-old had said she wasn't going to eat it, but once she smelled it baking she was begging to eat some too.  I served it along with corn and roasted potatoes seasoned with Italian seasonings, garlic, and parmesan cheese.  I've already had requests to make it again this week.  Thank you so much for a new family favorite!  Edit 01/12/09:  It's almost 1 year later and this is still my daughter's favorite way to eat chicken.  I like to serve it with a small side of fetuccine alfredo and steamed brocolli.

text:
Holy moistness!  How delicious.  I wanted to make this up a few hours ahead of time so I changed slightly to allow for this and not have the butter turn yucky.  I was short on the bread crumbs to so I compensated my loss with broken up butter crackers and added garlic powder(since I wasn't melting the butter with garlic I used powder) and salt and pepper to that.  I dredged the chicken in eggs and coated with these yummy crumbs.  I cut up the butter(which I only needed 1/4 stick) and laid it all over the bottom of my 13x9 inch dish and placed the chicken on that.  Then I sprinkled the cheese all over that.  So I didn't change the recipe just altered it to work for a make ahead dish.  FABULOUS!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight and it was really yummy.  I changed a few things based on other reviews, here is what I did:  I pounded my chicken breasts pretty thin; I used a mixture of cornflake crumbs and bread crumbs; I used basil instead of oregano; I dredged the chicken in flour before the butter and crumb/cheese mixture.  I also cut the recipe in half using 3 medium sized chicken breasts.  The end result was very moist, flavorful chicken which we will very likely make again.

text:
I made this recipe exactly as written.  I did have a hard time making the cheese to stick.  I sprinkled the leftovers on top of each breast before I baked them.  To begin with, it was very greasy.  But what do you expect with a whole stick of butter?  Next, I didn't like the sogginess on bottom compared to the crispiness on top.  Maybe you could solve this problem by baking the chicken on a broiler pan or a rack on a cookie sheet.  I probably won't make it again.  It definitely had a good flavor, but the whole recipe just wasn't good enough to put in a regular rotation.

LOVED THIS RECIPE!  Tasted better than I thought!   I  melted the butter in a dish in the microwave with the garlic, dipped my chicken, and used that same baking dish for the chicken to bake in.  Delicious!  Also substituted fresh parsley, which made a nice color combo to the rest of the ingredients.  Sprinkled the leftover bread crumbs and cheese as directed on top and the browning effect looked nice and tasted great. I cooked the chicken for almost a full hour, though (big boneless breasts) and it was juicy and yummy!

text:
I didn't necessarily think this was bad, but it definitely was not my favorite 'easy night' chicken recipe.  Like others, I had a difficult time making the bread crumb/ cheese mixture adhere to the chicken.  Also, after baking for a longer amount of time than expected, the chicken was still sitting in a greasy layer of 'juice' that made the crust rather soggy.  I may try this recipe again, but will most likely  reduce the amount of butter, and perhaps use cornflakes instead of bread crumbs (better crunch).

Display Name:
Erimess

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/414941.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as is, except for using low-fat margarine & low-fat cheese.  It was pretty good, though there's other similar recipes I've liked better, and was surprisingly filling for chicken.  I think it's important to pound the chicken, because it helped to cook it fast without burning the breading, and mine didn't get soggy.  I've only seen one other person comment on a difficulty of getting it to stick, but I did too.  It wasn't that there wasn't enough butter to allow the breading to stick -- it just wasn't, uh, sticky.  (Maybe cause of the cheese?)  I made sure the breading was spread on a wide, flat dish and then flipped the chicken over several times and really had to PRESS.  It still didn't stick great, so I took the leftovers and sprinkled it on top.  Kind of a pain, but that problem certainly didn't affect the flavor.
Review:
Rating:
5

This was great!  Tender, moist, and perfect.  I added an extra clove of garlic and omitted the salt.  I also baked for 40 minutes, turning the breasts over after 30 min.  I didn't believe how essential pounding the breasts thin was until I did it - do not skip that step!

Loved it!  I was only making it for 2 so I didn't measure out any of the ingredients quite exactly.  I used Italian seasoned bread crumbs, and instead of putting the butter and garlic on the stove I threw it in the microwave, and it cooked just fine.  After the chicken had been breaded, I sprinkled extra parmesan and cheddar cheese on top.  (Of course I didn't measure in the first place so maybe it wasn't extra!) city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thought it was very tasty, but some of the family weren't so keen. It had a very 'strong' flavour, and quite salty, although I didn't add any salt.

A nice 'buttery' flavour, but I too had to add more butter to finish off my chicken. May mix some oil with the butter next time, and see if that appeals to my lot more.

At first I covered it with foil as I was afraid the breadcrumbs and cheese would burn before the chicken was cooked through. Then I removed the foil later to let the coating crisp.

A nice variation on an 'escallope' dish.

text:
I agree with adenn - YUM YUM YUM!  I had 5 chicken breasts so I used 1/4 cup Smart Balance and a couple of tablespoons of olive oil in place of the butter and scaled down the breading - used panko bread crumbs plus a little toasted wheat germ, no parsley (didn't have any), added a little dried basil and used shredded taco cheese blend 'cause that's what I had on hand.  I was too lazy to pound the breasts so I just baked them around 40-45 minutes on a foil lined pan sprayed with Pam.  They came out moist and juicy and the breading was delicious.  The best part was picking the yummy breading off the pan!!  Hubby and daughter loved it too!

text:
Wow!!! This was incredible! The best chicken breast I ever had! I had 6 chicken breast and for my bread crumbs 
I used 2 slices of D'Italiano bread set out to dry a bit and then crumbled into little pieces. Had a little over a cup. Looks like they used bigger crumbs in the picture so that's what I did. Used one big clove and one small clove of garlic and that was plenty. I did everything else the same except I used powdered thyme instead of oregano. Had trouble getting the crumb mixture to stick so I just packed it on. Boy was it ever good!! Outside was crispy and golden and inside moist and tender and the aroma throughout the house was wonderful. Family raved. I would definately serve this to guests! Thank you so much for this recipe, we enjoyed every mouthful!!

This was a shock for me.  I only used 1 cup of cheddar cheese, didn't add the salt, and put pats of butter on top because I was afraid it was going to dry out.  It cooked in 20 minutes and my husband and son loved it!  They devoured it.  My hubby hates chicken and went on and on about how good this was.  I on the other hand was looking forward to it all day, and didn't really care for it.  I guess I'm not a big cheese fan, and although I am a salt lover still found this to be a bit salty.  Anyway it will be cooked again, it was loved by my boys and that's all that matters.  Thank you!

text:
This recipe did not come out for me. Like other reviewers, the breading was soggy. I will try this recipe again, but next time I will use cracker crumbs instead of bread crumbs. I seem to have better luck with crackers; they tend to hold up better than bread crumbs, and be nice and crispy. I also didn't pound the chicken, just cooked it a little longer.

text:
Great recipe - quick and easy, all ingredients that I keep on hand.  My husband just loved it!  I also made my own bread crumbs, didn't toast them or anything, and used Kraft grated parmesan and it came out terrific.  I think what made the flavor so great was the fact that I used sharp cheddar cheese.  I also added a little bit of Paula Dean's seasoning salt to the breading mixture - gave it a little kick!  I will definitely make this again.
